projectDesc.p: Text digitized and encoded for use in the Forager Folklore Database. The FFDB offers a basis for a systematic study of narrative universals, the evolutionary origin of storytelling, and (comparative) folklore studies.

samplingDecl.p: The narrative was selected for being a genuine piece of oral literature recorded directly (or via the proxy of an interpreter or other immediate intermediary) from an informant who either lived or grew up as a member of a culture whose primary subsistence at the time of recording was or until recently had been hunting, gathering, and/or fishing. Care was taken to ensure the quality of the recording and the relative freedom from external cultural influences. To create a corpus with high representability, multiple versions of the same narrative were omitted, cultural clusters and close cultural relations between two groups were negatively taken into account, and it was aimed for the highest degree of diversity.

editorialDecl.p: Footnotes are generally retained, but no effort has been made to link the narratives mentioned in comparative notes with corresponding records within the FFDB.
Page numbers have been retained, but page beginnings, pb, occuring within a word have been moved either before or after the word (or nominal phrase) with no clear systematic.

normalization.p: In-text explanations by the original editor are set in brackets. In-text additions/excursions by the informant are set in parenthesis.
Latin passages in the original (usually to hide language and themes deemed indecent) are rendered in English.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation has been removed. All other hyphenation has been retained.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained. No effort was made to mark quoted passages up as quote.

interpretation.p: Animals, plants, colors, characters, and place names were automatically tagged with a semantic tagger based on WordNet and on word lists as well as subsequently checked manually. They are tagged with animal , plant, color, persName and placeName, respectively.

item.term: A1611.1. Origin of American Indian tribes.
B610.1. Girl's animal lover slain by spying relatives.
C141.3. Tabu: not to enter water during menses.

body.p:
A Warrau man warned his sister not to bathe in a certain neighboring pond at those regular periods when she happened to be unwell [Sect. 188]. For a long time she obeyed his instructions, but after a time, forgetting all about them, she went to bathe at the forbidden spot and time, and was caught by a large snake, the water-camudi Uamma. By and by she became pregnant. Now it was during the bullet-tree [Mimusops belata] season, when the Indians used to cut down the trees to secure the seed, which are excellent eating, and it was noticed that this same woman, although she took no ax away with her in the morning, invariably returned with a large quantity of the delicious seed in the afternoon. The brother, thereupon becoming suspicious, watched her. Unobserved himself, he followed her next day, saw her approach a huge bullet-tree, and saw the Uamma snake [Sect. 244] sneaking out of the woman's body, coil around the tree, and make his way up into the topmost branches. There the snake changed into a man, who shook the boughs for the woman, thus causing the seeds to fall to the ground, where she gathered them. Having done this, the Uamma, reverting to his original form, descended the tree, and again
entered the woman's body. Thereupon the brother said, "There is something wrong here; this will not do: My sister probably has a snake in her body." So he told his friends who, in company with him, watched his sister the next day, when the same thing took place, Uamma sneaking out below the woman's body, climbing the tree, changing into human form, shaking the seeds down, and then becoming a snake again. But just as Uamma was about to reach the ground, the watchers rushed up and cut him into thousands of pieces. The woman grieved sorely, but collected all the fragments under a heap of mold and leaves, each piece of which by and by grew into a Carib. Many years passed; the Caribs growing strong and numerous, became a nation. They lived in harmony with the Warraus, so much so that when one tribe caught some game or other dainty, they would send a child with a piece of it over to the Warraus. The latter would then return the compliment and send a child of theirs with food to the Caribs. This lasted a long time, until one day the original mother of the Caribs - a very old woman now - told them to kill the child which the Warraus had sent to them; this was in revenge for the way the Warraus had slain her snake lover years before. As might have been expected, the Warraus on the next occasion slaughtered the Carib child, and thus a blood feud arose between the two nations, the Caribs finally overwhelming the Warraus.
